journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems

title-group.article-title: Effects of different shaped gold nanoparticles on the photoelectrode of dye-sensitized solar cells

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electronic Engineering, National Formosa University, Taiwan
2Department of Electrical Engineering, Hsiuping University of Science and Technology, Taiwan
3Department of Electro-Optical Engineering, Southern Taiwan University of Technology, Taiwan
4Institute of Electro-Optical and Materials Science, National Formosa University, Taiwan
5Department of Applied Physics, National University of Kaohsiung, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Teen-Hang Meen, Department of Electronic Engineering, National Formosa University, Hu-Wei, Yunlin 632, Taiwan. Email: thmeen@nfu.edu.tw

abstract.p: In this study, we prepared different shapes of gold nanoparticles by the seed-mediated growth method to apply on the photoelectrode of dye-sensitized solar cells. Analyses of field emission scanning electron microscopy and ultraviolet–visible absorption spectra show that the average diameter of spherical gold nanoparticles is 66 nm and gold nanorods in aspect ratio is 2. The best conversion efficiencies of dye-sensitized solar cell with spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods added in are 6.77 and 7.08%, and are higher than that without gold nanoparticles. These results indicate that the effect of gold nanoparticles on the photoelectrode can increase the conductivity and reduce the recombination of charges in the photoelectrode, resulting in the increase of conversion efficiency for dye-sensitized solar cells. Futhermore, gold nanorods have stronger surface plasmon resonance intensity than spherical gold nanoparticles at long wavelength. This may be the reason why conversion efficiency of dye-sensitized solar cells with gold nanorods is higher than that of spherical gold nanoparticles.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, a new type of solar cell based on dye-sensitized nano-crystalline titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been developed by Grätzel and coworkers.1 The most attractive features of this technology are reduced production costs and ease of manufacture. Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) based on nano-crystalline TiO2 electrodes are currently attracting widespread attention as a low-cost alternative to replace conventional inorganic photovoltaic devices.2–6 The function of DSSCs is based upon the injection of electrons of photo-excited state of the sensitizer dye into the conduction band of the semiconductor. Many research studies have attempted to achieve four goals: to promote the adsorption of dye, to harvest more solar light, to smooth the progress of transport of photo-excited electrons, and to facilitate the diffusion of an electrolyte ion. A record of the cell convertible efficiency of 11% was achieved by using N3 (RuL2(NCS)2, L = 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid) dye and the electrolyte containing guanidinium thiocyanate.7 Grätzel and co-workers used DSSCs sensitized by N3 dye using gaunidinium thiocyanate as self-assembly facilitating agent, leading to improvement in efficiency.8–11 Some of the cheaper dyes have also been used as sensitizers to improve absorption in the visible region.12–14 Gold nanoparticles can not only increase the conductivity, the different shapes will also have different intensity of surface plasmon resonance (SPR).15 Recent studies have shown that metal or metal ion doped semiconductor composites exhibit a shift in the Fermi level to more negative potentials. Such a shift in the Fermi level improves the energetics of the composite system and enhances the efficiency of the interfacial charge-transfer process.16 In addition, Chou et al.17 prepared TiO2/nano-metal composite particles by a dry particle coating technique. This study shows that the power conversion efficiency η of the DSSCs with a film of TiO2/Au (or TiO2/Ag) on the working electrode always exceeds that of the conventional DSSCs owing to the presence of the Schottky barrier. In the present study, we prepared different shapes of gold nanoparticles by the seed-mediated growth method to apply on the photoelectrode of DSSCs. The gold nanoparticles and DSSCs were investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), ultraviolet-visible absorption spectra (UV-vis), and current-voltage characteristics analyses to study the effects of different shapes of gold nanoparticles on the photoelectrode of DSSCs.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: Hydrogen tetrachloroaurate(III) trihydrate (HAuCl4·3H2O, 99.9%), hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99.8%), ascorbic acid (AA, 99.7%) and sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 99.9%) were used as reactants. TiO2 powder and 4-tert-butylpyridine are the preparation paste for the photoelectrode. The deionized (DI) water that was used throughout the experiments was purified using a Milli-Q system. Glassware was cleaned by soaking it in aqua regia and then washing it with DI water.

sec.title: Synthesis of gold nanoparticles
sec.p: We used the seed-mediated growth method to prepare the gold nanoparticles. This method involves two main steps.

list-item.p: Preparation of seed solution. Gold seed solution was prepared by first combining HAuCl4·3H2O (5 mL, 0.5 mM) and CTAB (5 mL, 0.2M), followed by addition of freshly made NaBH4 (0.6 mL, 0.01M) under vigorous stirring. Then the mixture was left undisturbed and aged for 2 h at 25 °C until further use.

Preparation of growth solution. The growth solution consists of HAuCl4·3H2O (5 mL, 1 mM), AgNO3 (spherical and rod-shaped are 0.01M and 0.04M, respectively, all 0.2 mL) and CTAB (5 mL, 0.2M). AA (70 µL, 0.0788M) was then added, and followed by brief stirring (∼1 min). Lastly, 25 µL of the seed solution was added to the growth solution. The mixture was allowed to react at 30 °C. Centrifugation of the gold nanoparticles was carried out at 4000 r/min for 20 min and the supernatant was removed and then resuspended with the same volume of DI water. This process was repeated three times.

sec.title: Assembling the DSSC
sec.p: We used the scraper method to prepare the photoelectrode on FTO-glass (fluorine doped tin oxide (SnO2:F)) substrate. The TiO2 coatings were prepared from commercial TiO2 particles (P25). The composition of the TiO2 paste was TiO2, 4-tert-butylpyridine and DI water. The concentration of TiO2 paste was 10 wt%. With the quantitative addition of gold nanoparticles, the TiO2 film was scraped to the desired thickness on the substrate. After drying, we pressed TiO2 film using a suitable pressure and annealed at 450 °C for 30 min to complete the photoelectrode. The size of the TiO2 films electrodes used was 0.25 cm2 (0.5 cm × 0.5 cm). Finally, we kept the photoelectrode immersed in a mixture containing a (3 × 10−4 M) solution of N3 dye and ethyl alcohol at 45 °C for 1.5 h in the oven. The electrode was assembled into a sandwich-type open cell using a platinum plate as the counter electrode.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The surface morphology of samples was observed using FE-SEM. Element content of the samples was observed by EDS. The UV-vis spectrum of samples was observed by a UV-vis spectrophotometer. The current–voltage characteristics of samples were measured by Keithley 2400 source meter and determined under simulated sunlight with white light intensity PL=100 mW/cm2.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the FE-SEM images of gold nanoparticles. The average diameter of spherical gold nanoparticles is 66 nm and gold nanorods in aspect ratio is 2. The UV-vis absorption spectra of gold nanoparticles are shown in Figure 2. The standard absorption wavelength is about 540 nm for spherical gold nanoparticles. The absorption of gold nanorods reveals two peaks. One is about 510–520 nm, and the other is about 654 nm. Figure 3 shows FE-SEM images of TiO2 films without and with gold nanoparticles added. The films are all smooth, as shown in Figure 3 (a) to (c). The thickness of these TiO2 films was about 23 µm. Figure 4 shows the analysis of EDS for TiO2 film without gold nanoparticles added. The figure shows that the elements of TiO2 film contain Ti and O, and the atomic ratio is about 1:2. Figures 5 and 6 show the analyses of EDS for TiO2 film with spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods added. The amount of spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods is about 0.23 and 0.18 at% in TiO2 films. Figure 7 shows the UV-vis absorption spectrum of TiO2 films without and with gold nanoparticles added. It is found that the absorption spectrum of TiO2 film with gold nanoparticles added is better than that without gold nanoparticles, and the film with gold nanorods has stronger SPR intensity than spherical gold nanoparticles at long wavelength.

caption.p: FE-SEM images of (a) spherical gold nanoparticles; (b) gold nanorods.
The UV-vis absorption spectrum of spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods.

FE-SEM images of the TiO2 films: (a), (b), (c) are top view; (d), (e), (f) are side view. (a) and (d) are without gold nanoparticles added. (b) and (e) are with spherical gold nanoparticles added. (c) and (f) are with gold nanorods added.
EDS analysis for TiO2 film without gold nanoparticles added.
EDS analysis for TiO2 film with spherical gold nanoparticles added.
EDS analysis for TiO2 film with gold nanorods added.
The UV-vis absorption spectrum of TiO2 films without and with gold nanoparticles added.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the current–voltage characteristics of DSSCs without and with gold nanoparticles added. The parameters for the short-circuit current density (Jsc), the open circuit potential (Voc), the fill factor (FF) and the overall conversion efficiency (η) are listed in Table 1. It is found that the best conversion efficiencies of DSSCs with spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods added are 6.77 and 7.08%, which are higher than that without gold nanoparticles. It is noted that the conversion efficiency of DSSCs with gold nanorods added is higher than that of spherical gold nanoparticles. This may be due to gold nanorods having a stronger SPR effect on the TiO2 photoelectrode than that of spherical gold nanoparticles. From the results of Figure 8 and Table 1, the effect of gold nanoparticles on the TiO2 photoelectrode can increase the conductivity and reduce the recombination of charges in the photoelectrode, resulting in an increase of conversion efficiency for DSSCs.

caption.p: The current –voltage (J–V) (J−V) curves of DSSCs without and with gold nanoparticles added.
The parameters of current–voltage characteristics for DSSCs with different shaped gold nanoparticles.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, we prepared gold nanoparticles by seed-mediated growth method to apply on the photoelectrode of DSSCs. The best conversion efficiencies of DSSCs with spherical gold nanoparticles and gold nanorods added are 6.77 and 7.08%, and these values are higher than that without gold nanoparticles, which is 6.21%. The conversion efficiency of DSSCs with gold nanorods added is higher than that of spherical gold nanoparticles. These results indicate that the effect of gold nanoparticles on the photoelectrode can be an increase in the conductivity and a reduction in the recombination of charges in the photoelectrode, resulting in an increase of conversion efficiency for DSSCs.
